thread.section_title: Texas Tech Red Raiders News - Sports News for Dallas, Texas
thread.title: Baylor's Linwood sets career high with 221 yards against Tech
thread.title_full: Baylor's Linwood sets career high with 221 yards against Texas Tech | Dallas Morning News

author: Brad Townsend
title: Baylor's Linwood sets career high with 221 yards against Tech
text:
ARLINGTON -- Baylor running back Shock Linwood's ability and credentials have never been in question.
The junior from Linden-Kildare set Baylor freshman and sophomore rushing records. On Saturday at AT&T Stadium, though, he showcased another dimension -- breakaway speed.
On the third play from scrimmage, he sped through a gaping hole at right tackle -- "clear as day," Linwood said -- and raced 79 yards for a touchdown.
His previous career long was 49 yards against Kansas in 2013.
"We've actually been wanting him to have [a long] one for a while," Baylor coach Art Briles said.
Briles and Linwood credited Baylor's improved offensive line, the fact that quarterback Seth Russell is a run threat and the fact the Bears are more balanced offensively as reasons Linwood could reel off more long-distance runs.
Linwood's career-high 221 yards Saturday was third-most in Baylor history and moved him past Jay Finley and into third on the career rushing list.
With 2,717 yards, Linwood trails only Walter Abercrombie (3,665) and Jerod Douglas (2,811).
Kingsbury critiques Mahomes: Tech coach Kliff Kingsbury said quarterback Pat Mahomes, who threw for 415 yards, three touchdowns and two interceptions, "played fairly well."
Mahomes set a Big 12 freshman record with 598 yards on 30-of-56 passing and six touchdowns a year ago against Baylor.
"He got behind and got out of our game plan, so it was tough," Kingsbury said.
Lauderdale leaves with injury: Texas Tech junior receiver Devin Lauderdale, who came into the game with 307 receiving yards, caught three passes for 16 yards before leaving with an undisclosed injury.
After the game, Kingsbury said he was not sure of Lauderdale's status.
Coleman climbs charts: Baylor junior receiver Corey Coleman, a Richardson Pearce product, had touchdown receptions of 24, 16 and 16 yards, bringing his career total to 24.
That ties Tevin Reese for third on Baylor's career list, behind Kendall Wright (30) and Cowboys receiver Terrance Williams (27).
Grant's first-half drops hurt: Jakeem Grant caught six passes for 69 yards, but Kingsbury said two of Grant's drops were glaring.
One of the drops was on a third down, "and you've got make those plays," Kingsbury said. "Anytime you have those and you have a game going back and forth like that, it's going to hurt."
